subject: Require container & disk formats on image create
messages:
[{'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-02-17 16:34:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-02-17 17:13:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(1 inline comment)

Excellent work. I'm actually kicking myself for not catching this earlier.

The only thing that needs to be added is a migration script that updates any image database entries that have disk_format or container_format set to NULL or "" to their respective values...'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-02-17 17:29:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Does it *really* make sense to default? We handle images differently based on these parameters, and I'm not sure there is a way to provide a sane default without diving into the image contents itself."}, {'account_id': 144, 'date': '2012-02-17 17:47:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thanks for addressing the bug I reported, and sorry for causing so much trouble!

From my point of view as an API consumer, it's fine to raise an error if I don't provide something that's required, as you do with name (although I think I've just discovered that name isn't checked in the API either).  Perversely, that's probably nicer than defaulting to something I may or may not expect.  However if the parameter wasn't required in the past and there are lots of API consumers that would break if you now require it, then you should default to maintain backwards compatibility.  Just my two cents; I don't know which applies here."}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-02-17 17:52:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I agree we shouldn't break consumers of our API where possible, but in this case do you think there could even be a reasonable consumer depending on this behavior? We could have clients posting requests without container/disk_format, but trying to use the images after that would be useless, wouldn't it?"}, {'account_id': 144, 'date': '2012-02-17 18:01:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Good point Brian - I didn't quite realize why these fields were actually required, but of course it's because nova expects them.  I've checked my code, and I do specify them (when I'm not writing a test for the API binding!)  Throwing an error would be fine with me as API consumer, but the decision is up to you guys.

Is name supposed to be required as well?  I don't have to specify it when doing the API call, but I do have to specify it when using the CLI."}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-02-17 18:12:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Hi Brian,

Hmmm, that's an interesting thought. I suppose the main point was to ensure that if the container/disk formats were defaulted via one path (the CLI) then they should be consitently defaulted via *every* code path.

Seems we have a number of options here:

0. go with the across-the-board defaults as implemeted in this patch

1. require that the container/disk format always be explicitly specified upfront on image creation

2. always leave the container/disk format metadata unset if not explicitly specified (as is currently the situation with the python/REST APIs)

3. crack open the image and attempt to detect any formats left unspecified

Option #3 would obviously require a fool-proof method of detection for all types we support. It would also be slightly problematic in the external storage case (i.e. x-image-meta-location set) as the image content isn't currently seen by glance immediately on creation."}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-02-17 18:18:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

It doesn't seem useful to me at all to allow users to create partially-defined images. The glance cli won't have to change yet since it provides a default, and I know the code in nova that talks directly to the api sends container/disk_formats. Let's raise a 400 on these missing fields."}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-02-17 19:16:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> It doesn't seem useful to me at all to allow users to create partially-defined images. 

Agreed. 

> The glance cli won't have to change yet since it provides a default

Seems to me that if the ovf/raw defaults make sense for the CLI, then they should also make sense for the direct calls on the REST API. Conversely, if defaulting is not sensible for the API, then it wouldn't be either for the CLI. I don't think the ovf/raw assumption is any more or less likely to be correct for either style of calling into glance (unless I'm missing something ...)

> I know the code in nova that talks directly to the api sends container/disk_formats

Cool.

> Let's raise a 400 on these missing fields.

So if a 400 is returned from the API, then IMO the CLI should either consider the container/disk_format params to be mandatory or else just pass thru' exactly whatever the provided and allow the API layer is reject it if necessary."}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-02-17 20:48:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

commit_message:
Require container & disk formats on image create

Fixes lp 933702

For images created via the glance CLI, the container and disk formats
were previously defaulted if not explicitly set. However if created via
the python or REST APIs, these attributes were not defaulted if unset.

There is no real sensible default for these formats, so now an image
create fails with 400 "Bad Request" if the format metadata are missing.

Also we ensure unset image metadata are not reported in x-image-meta-*
headers in order to disambiguate None and empty string values.

Change-Id: I8189383f5f9adf42a8cdac7f8dc7e9327baf46da

commit_message:
Don't tell Qpid to reconnect in a busy loop.

Fix bug 929784.

Don't set any of the reconnect timing options unless they have been set
in the configuration.  Setting them all to zero puts Qpid in a mode
where it will reconnect in a busy loop.  By not setting these unless a
non-zero value has been provided, Qpid goes back to its default
behavior, which is to use an exponential backoff on reconnect attempts
(after 1 second, then 2, 4, 8, etc).

Change-Id: Ia587bbe96db9ea6e429af289c3d586f4c6706648

commit_message:
Add additional information to servers output.

 * Improves cloud debugability, by letting admins see on which host a
   server has been launched
 * Addresses blueprint optional-host-and-admin-information
 * Add test
 * Rebase to master, fix tests accordingly

Change-Id: Iba173ca3b1ead716e274f1d287cebbc7961d8a93

Also, what I'd really like to do is use a tool like this which would generate a config file full of comments e.g.

etc."}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2012-02-06 15:40:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

There's a bunch of work I'd like to do here e.g.

 * We should just import the modules and only look at nova.flags.FLAGS when they're all imported

 * I'd prefer the output to be .ini style rather than flagfile style
 * The output should only contain comments - i.e. each option default should be commented out

But this is good a enough start to go in, I think"}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-02-20 06:53:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 17: No score

Fixes nova aspect of lp 837464

Prevously only Zulu time was supported in the changes-since filter,
i.e. timestamps formatted as %Y-%m-%dT%H:%M:%SZ

We now support arbitrary timezones, with the offset from UTC expressed
via the ISO 8601 ±hh:mm notation.

Microsecond accurracy is also optionally supported in timestamps.

Notes:

- nova.utils.parse_isotime(), isotime() & normalized_time() are
  prime candidates for promotion to openstack-common, as these
  methods were duplicated from my corresponding glance patch:

    https://review.openstack.org/#change,4198

- this patch introduces a new dependency on python-iso8601, which
  has already been packaged for Fedora, EPEL and Ubuntu/Debian.

Change-Id: I89b45f4f3d910606c578d927420f78cea94f4e3b

commit_message:
Support non-UTC timestamps in changes-since filter

Fixes nova aspect of lp 837464

Prevously only Zulu time was supported in the changes-since filter,
i.e. timestamps formatted as %Y-%m-%dT%H:%M:%SZ

We now support arbitrary timezones, with the offset from UTC expressed
via the ISO 8601 ±hh:mm notation.

Microsecond accurracy is also optionally supported in timestamps.

Notes:

- nova.utils.parse_isotime(), isotime() & normalized_time() are
  prime candidates for promotion to openstack-common, as these
  methods were duplicated from my corresponding glance patch:

    https://review.openstack.org/#change,4198

- this patch introduces a new dependency on python-iso8601, which
  has already been packaged for Fedora, EPEL and Ubuntu/Debian.

Change-Id: I89b45f4f3d910606c578d927420f78cea94f4e3b

subject: Add git vcsversion method.
messages:
[{'account_id': 2, 'date': '2012-02-20 06:32:09.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 2, 'date': '2012-02-20 06:32:09.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 2, 'date': '2012-02-20 06:32:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

We do tag - but git-describe doesn't actually meet our needs for a couple of reasons.

One is that the version number it outputs directly conflicts with debian version number parsing (the dash is quite problematic)

But the second is that we do version numbers as pre-release _before_ the version we're going to be releasing, rather than as post-release increments after a released tag. Talk to Theirry about about one - he's pretty adamant about it. :)

That being said - making our use of automatic versioning more sane is definitely on my todo list :)"}, {'account_id': 2, 'date': '2012-02-20 06:32:09.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 2, 'date': '2012-02-20 06:32:09.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 236, 'date': '2012-02-20 06:32:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

(1 inline comment)

This looks ok. I am wondering why we are not properly tagging our branches, since then we could just use "git describe".'}, {'account_id': 236, 'date': '2012-02-20 06:32:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Looks good.'}, {'account_id': 385, 'date': '2012-02-20 06:32:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

(5 inline comments)

Few issues, the local branch name usage being the blocker

Would be nice to have tests too"}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-02-20 06:32:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

I think I'd prefer _run_shell_command() and _canonicalize_email() - i.e. make them private and choose better names"}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-02-20 06:32:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

commit_message:
Add git vcsversion method.

Leaving in the branch_nick for now - I think we need to go through the
projects using this code and ensure that they aren't going to get screwed
before we remove it.

Change-Id: Ib91b5af050244f44cd811ca47cb6e2c53ef74ddb

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-02-03 14:28:10.000000000', 'message': "Fixes 925599, typos in image admin guide

Minor updates to Keystone install docs

- RAX-KEY is deprecated
- Correct service name for glance is 'image-service'

Change-Id: I21c0423b619338ce6246b289da194b23819a0abf

Keystone config permission should be 0640, not 0644

The docs incorrectly specified that the keystone config permission should be
0644, but that would provide all users on the system access to the mysql
password.

This fixes the typo, and explicitly adds the chmod and chown.

Change-Id: Ia81effd54e1bb4b66b9fd84e4c753fff950ce0bc

Add rate limit documentation

Change-Id: I1f6821323eb2cfee980d9425795ca07e7206de66

Change-Id: Iacf0d448875b0bc71c6ec3404d492579499a3bfb

Minor updates to Keystone install docs

- RAX-KEY is deprecated
- Correct service name for glance is 'image-service'

Change-Id: I21c0423b619338ce6246b289da194b23819a0abf

Keystone config permission should be 0640, not 0644

The docs incorrectly specified that the keystone config permission should be
0644, but that would provide all users on the system access to the mysql

Change-Id: Ia81effd54e1bb4b66b9fd84e4c753fff950ce0bc

commit_message:
Fixes 925599, typos in image admin guide
Deletes chapter files that aren't referred to in the image admin guide
Renames image admin guide to start with bk_
Minor updates to Keystone install docs

- RAX-KEY is deprecated
- Correct service name for glance is 'image-service'

Change-Id: I21c0423b619338ce6246b289da194b23819a0abf

Keystone config permission should be 0640, not 0644

The docs incorrectly specified that the keystone config permission should be
0644, but that would provide all users on the system access to the mysql
password.

This fixes the typo, and explicitly adds the chmod and chown.

Change-Id: Ia81effd54e1bb4b66b9fd84e4c753fff950ce0bc

Add rate limit documentation

Change-Id: I1f6821323eb2cfee980d9425795ca07e7206de66

Fixes 92559, improvements to Image Admin guide

Change-Id: Iacf0d448875b0bc71c6ec3404d492579499a3bfb

Fixes glance aspect of lp 837464

Prevously only Zulu time was supported in the changes-since filter,
i.e. timestamps formatted as %Y-%m-%dT%H:%M:%SZ

We now support arbitrary timezones, with the offset from UTC expressed
via the ISO 8601 ±hh:mm notation.

Microsecond accurracy is also optionally supported in timestamps.

commit_message:
Support non-UTC timestamps in changes-since filter

Fixes glance aspect of lp 837464

Prevously only Zulu time was supported in the changes-since filter,
i.e. timestamps formatted as %Y-%m-%dT%H:%M:%SZ

We now support arbitrary timezones, with the offset from UTC expressed
via the ISO 8601 ±hh:mm notation.

Microsecond accurracy is also optionally supported in timestamps.

Notes:

- glance.common.utils.parse_isotime(), isotime(), & normalize_time()
  are prime candidates for promotion to openstack-common, as these
  methods will be useful in nova also

- this patch introduces a new dependency on python-iso8601, which
  has already been packaged for Fedora, EPEL and Ubuntu/Debian.

Change-Id: I4c80522bcaa14feef93f5f9fbcaaca6a74b6a5f4

commit_message:
Add python-iso8601 to nova and glance dependencies

Nova and glance will shortly require the python-iso8601 package in
order to support non-UTC timestamps in the changes-since filter.

In particular, the following nova patch is blocked by devstack
failing due to the missing dependency:

  https://review.openstack.org/#change,4211

Change-Id: Iaae8812cf19c9ae1ad237b7fda7d99827aca1485

commit_message:
Move connection pool back into impl_kombu/qpid.

Fix bug 928996.

This patch moves the creation of the connection pool from nova.rpc.amqp
back into nova.rpc.impl_kombu and nova.rpc.impl_qpid.  The pool now gets
passed into nova.rpc.amqp using arguments as needed.

The previous method worked fine unless both rpc implementations got
loaded into the same Python instance.  In that case, whichever one got
loaded 2nd had control over what type of connections nova.rpc.amqp would
create.  With these changes in place, this conflict between impl_kombu
and impl_qpid is resolved.

Change-Id: I72bc0c95bfc04ccdfb89d3456332f622ca5ffa42

subject: Allow to override SysLogHandler /dev/log with $SWIFT_SYSLOG_ADDRESS for tests
messages:
[{'account_id': 597, 'date': '2012-01-30 15:04:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Why use OS environment variable and not config? I do not understand this decision.'}, {'account_id': 2400, 'date': '2012-01-30 16:01:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

You are right. Based on the number of occurrences of get_logger in the tree I thought that passing it via config would mean too many modifications. But in fact one change is enough for the tests. I will resubmit.'}, {'account_id': 2400, 'date': '2012-01-30 16:58:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Restored

Duh, I was too quick, applying the wrong patch. Reopening...

Using a config dict is tedious, because it is passed as an empty literal all over the unit tests. 	
See what it takes to reduce the number of failures from 348 to 285:
https://gist.github.com/1705350

So, that's why. It doesn't seem much cleaner either. But as a newcomer I am ready to learn the proper way, just give me pointers.

BTW Change 3356 shows the context in which this is applied: https://review.openstack.org/#change,3356
(I was meanwhile advised to continue working in a single Gerrit Change, will do from now on.)"}, {'account_id': 597, 'date': '2012-01-30 17:39:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Thanks a lot for the gist link, that explains it. I still hate adding environment variables but perhaps no other way exist. My interest is because that /dev/log is an issue when running Siwft in a chroot.'}, {'account_id': 167, 'date': '2012-01-30 19:05:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

As described in my comment to change https://review.openstack.org/#change,3541 I would prefer not introducing new environment variables, too.'}, {'account_id': 894, 'date': '2012-02-02 17:56:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I don't like too much that syslog code. It uses "/dev/log", which is the right thing to do if you're using syslog over a unix socket, but there's no way of supporting UDP.

It should implement a fallback (such as: https://github.com/Memset/sftpcloudfs/blob/master/sftpcloudfs/main.py#L211), so it uses UDP if there's no Unix socket (ie. chroot, or Mac OS; although I don't know if Swift can run on that OS heh), or just add a configuration token.

The configuration looks sexy because it can be used in tests too.

What do you think?'}, {'account_id': 894, 'date': '2012-02-03 10:45:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

subject: Setting access ip values on server create.
messages:
[{'account_id': 998, 'date': '2012-02-14 21:09:16.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 998, 'date': '2012-02-14 21:49:38.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-02-15 22:18:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Do not submit

(1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 998, 'date': '2012-02-17 04:58:39.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 998, 'date': '2012-02-17 06:17:47.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-02-17 14:36:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: (6 inline comments)

Sorry, I guess I should have noticed before that the network info was already retrieved in _run_instance..  vs suggesting to use a network_api call.  See inline.

Also:  Should we update access IPs if a user passed them in?   It seems like we shouldn't overwrite information that the user may have passed in w/ a server create.  I wonder if 'is_first_time' should really be 'set_access_ips' and... we should only pass it in as True to the scheduler run_instance call... 'if not access_ip_v4 and not access_ip_v6' (or maybe both set_ipv4_access_ip and set_ipv6_access_ip options are needed.. hm)."}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-02-17 14:41:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: (1 inline comment)

Clarified something inline...based on my last comment.'}, {'account_id': 998, 'date': '2012-02-17 16:50:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Chris, you are right, we should not update the access ip values if the user had provided them in their create server request. But I think it would be cleaner if we kept the is_first_time param, and just check if the instance already has access ips set before we update them.'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-02-17 17:04:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

I can live with that.  Something bugs me about the 'is_first_time' thing... but I'll get over it. :)"}, {'account_id': 998, 'date': '2012-02-17 17:17:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

I added is_first_time as a param of the function run_instance. It means this is the first time this instance is run. It allows us to do any housekeeping that is needed the first time a server is started up. Hope that helps :)'}, {'account_id': 998, 'date': '2012-02-17 20:04:36.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-02-17 20:10:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

:)   I'm good w/ it now!   Thanks for the updates!"}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-02-17 20:12:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 67, 'name': 'Vish Ishaya', 'email': 'vishvananda@gmail.com', 'username': 'vishvananda'}, {'_account_id': 100, 'name': 'Johannes Erdfelt', 'email': 'johannes@erdfelt.com', 'username': 'johannes.erdfelt'}, {'_account_id': 679, 'name': 'Kevin L. Mitchell', 'email': 'klmitch@mit.edu', 'username': 'klmitch'}, {'_account_id': 1419, 'name': 'Mike Pittaro', 'email': 'mikeyp@LaHondaResearch.org', 'username': 'mikeyp-3'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 1419, 'date': '2012-02-14 01:44:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I'm putting this up for some early feedback, to see if the approach makes sense.   

In short, we 'inject' the root password into the mounted filesystem at boot time using the usermod utility.  This avoids the need for a user agent, but does require the usermod utility to be in the image."}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-02-14 01:55:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Approach seems reasonable to me.  It makes me cringe to mess with instances so much, but once we support a more robust metadata service, this can be done by a guest agent like cloud-init.  It makes sense to give the deployers the option to use password injection if they really need it for some reason.'}, {'account_id': 1419, 'date': '2012-02-15 00:18:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-02-15 00:22:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: (8 inline comments)

I'm okay adding this so we get some sort of password injection for libvirt. Please see my comments inline."}, {'account_id': 1419, 'date': '2012-02-15 00:36:31.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 1419, 'date': '2012-02-15 00:37:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (2 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 1419, 'date': '2012-02-15 00:38:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

This patch set resolves the formatting issues'}, {'account_id': 1419, 'date': '2012-02-15 17:12:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Lets hold off on this for now - it introduces a serious security hole.  Will upload an alternative approach.'}, {'account_id': 1419, 'date': '2012-02-17 01:10:58.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-02-17 19:59:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(2 inline comments)

Really don't like defaulting to DES-style passwords…"}, {'account_id': 1419, 'date': '2012-02-17 23:10:41.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 1419, 'date': '2012-02-17 23:13:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: (2 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 1419, 'date': '2012-02-17 23:15:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Patch Set 5 now defaults to an md5 hash, with DES fallback.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-02-17 23:18:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-02-17 23:34:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

commit_message:
Add support for admin_password to LibVirt

If the config flag --libvirt_inject_password is set, Libvirt now makes
an attempt to inject the admin_password to instances at startup time.

Fixes bug 767202

Change-Id: I1491c84825bf0bbad43a7d53b379271caa2b76f6

commit_message:
fix pre_block_migration() interaction with libvirt cache

Fixes bug 932179

* nova/virt/libvirt/connection (pre_block_migration):
Don't pass the 'ephemeral_gb' attribute as the size,
since this has the wrong units and is the wrong quantity
to pass anyway.  Also don't check for file existence,
or create the cow image as this is done within _cache_image()

Change-Id: Id723ec8d119dacd4660e88e546e05af417c736fc

    2 the exception listed in the bug, which was caused by tring to load data for a deleted instance.

commit_message:
Fix traceback running instance-usage-audit

There were two errors here:
    1 was a missed joinload that was causing an error pulling info_cache.
    2 the exception listed in the bug, which was caused by tring to load data for a deleted instance.

This fixes bug 934539

Change-Id: Ifffb6a35c1f7bf8caa6f57d33b29b58d0dbe10b3

commit_message:
remove unused nwfilter methods and tests.

remove unused methods and classes in nova/virt/libvirt/firewall.py
and releative function tests. now,nova use nwfilter offered by
libvirt only for anti ARP and IP spoofing.other security policy use
iptables.

Change-Id: Ib9866802ef64668e2feba09124bdf7c7fee92f92

commit_message:
Fixed #934459. Remove outdated -E arg for pip.

Pip no longer supports -E, and since we were running pip from inside
the virtualenv anyway, it was unnecessary.

Change-Id: I423e2842afe28ac365a13e7f8e492095f3685dd3

commit_message:
Fixes nova-volume support for multiple luns

 * stores lun in provider_location if specified
 * passes lun in iscsi_properties instead of hard coding
 * adds call to libvirt to list all used block devices
 * make sure to synchronize connect and disconnect commands
 * only disconnect from target if no luns are in use
 * allow double logins to targets
 * fixes typo in get_volume_connector in xenapi_connection
 * fixes bug 929790

Change-Id: I2466dc750a6fa5e0b07f94314d38873740aa6b29

commit_message:
Fix bug 933147 Security group trigger notifications.

Add a lightweight mechanism to allow security group trigger
notifications to be propagated to quantum security group handlers.

Add a global flag: "security_group_handler" to allow for runtime
selection of security group handler class.

Change-Id: I8a3768c26c97020071ad4e52d3a22d8898e72e9f

commit_message:
Fix troubles with git cloning https

Some xenservers get errors because git is not configured with
curl and expat, and because of invalid SSL certs.

Change-Id: Ibe7062255b90559b0d6ca5f52e33ec56451505df

subject: fix checksum writing in libvirt image cache
messages:
[{'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-02-10 14:56:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

nice catch'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-02-10 20:52:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 2271, 'date': '2012-02-10 21:40:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Thanks for fixing this for me.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-02-13 23:37:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(1 inline comment)

"}, {'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2012-02-14 01:21:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Fair point. Actually looking at the code, I'm a bit confused.
Michael why is the checksum just done in connection._fetch_image()?

Shouldn't it be done also utils.fetch_image()?

Or even better, just within connection._cache_image()."}, {'account_id': 2271, 'date': '2012-02-14 20:39:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

The short answer is I don't recall why this checksum is written in _fetch_image instead of _cache_image. I think this code needs a larger reworking -- for example, there should be a checksum for both the original image from glance and the resized image, which isn't the case.

I agree this code should be moved into _cache_image."}, {'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2012-02-17 22:51:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

Vish has removed this redundant method anyway in
https://review.openstack.org/#change,4143

Checksumming will need to be looked at again'}]

commit_message:
fix checksum writing in libvirt image cache

* nova/virt/libvirt/connection.py (_fetch_image): Fix a typo
which would have caused an exception when writing the image checksum

Change-Id: I9d3f330e2ce9fe9a54cbcec4cffbcd078bc3d78c

commit_message:
Pulls the main components out of deallocate.

deallocate_for_instances is basically deallocate
the port, then delete the vif. This separates
them.

update one: hacking within the lines
update two: another hacking fix
update three: rebase
update four: rebase and detrailingslashify

Change-Id: I01e06a9225d7825af5d404d5815f5084c7660799

Looks good.  I wonder if it be useful at some point to always store the exc_info in a new column, even for non-admin users.  Just don't display it to them otherwise."}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-02-16 19:07:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

Looks good.

Already approved so don't worry about it, but I included a small nit inline"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-02-16 19:07:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Fails

Build Failed 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-integration-tests-devstack-vm/1526/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-merge/1411/ : This change was unable to be automatically merged with the current state of the repository. Please rebase your change and upload a new patchset. 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-unittests/1031/ : FAILURE 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-pep8/2792/ : FAILURE'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-02-16 19:09:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: No score; No score

Rick: Yeah, I saw that nit too and I agree.  Well, he can fix it now ;)

Alex: since this failed, I'm also curious about the switch of exception from Error to Invalid when setting admin password."}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2012-02-16 19:14:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: No score

'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-02-17 06:09:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

Looking at the change more I'm not sure I completely understand why the status code is being checked. Is this merely to differentiate between hard errors (real bugs) and soft errors (invalid data being sent)?"}, {'account_id': 177, 'date': '2012-02-17 17:21:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

First off, thanks for the reviews guys. This branch has gotten me a little code blind.

Chris: I switched the admin password failure to invalid for the case where it's not a complex enough password but I suppose since this is actually catching any exception we shouldn't do that. I'll change it back.

Johannes: Yes that's correct. I may change this though.

I think I am also going to change an instance fault message to be the actual exception and details will always be the traceback. That way, normal users will get a more helpful description of an error and tracebacks will always be paired with an easy to read description. We'll just never show details to a normal user."}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-02-17 17:33:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Exceptions should not be shown to a user. Please see these bugs for examples of why this is a bad idea:

https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/868360

https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/874472'}, {'account_id': 177, 'date': '2012-02-17 18:23:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

so a user would only ever see the exception name? or are we still showing soft exceptions to the user (Those with other than 500 code)?

We will never show a user a traceback of course'}, {'account_id': 177, 'date': '2012-02-17 18:44:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-02-17 19:12:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

I don't know how useful it is for a user to see an exception name at all. What will they do with that information?"}, {'account_id': 177, 'date': '2012-02-17 19:14:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

That's what I'm thinking"}, {'account_id': 177, 'date': '2012-02-17 19:52:40.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 177, 'date': '2012-02-17 19:55:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

This will always put the exception name in the message field (as it currently does). Details will contain the exception for normal users if it is not a 500 error and admins will be able to see 500's and their tracebacks.

I don't think it should be this way forever and instance faults needs some reworking. But for now this will make them useful."}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-02-17 20:10:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-02-17 20:18:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (1 inline comment)

inline'}, {'account_id': 177, 'date': '2012-02-17 20:23:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 177, 'date': '2012-02-17 20:24:02.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-02-17 20:33:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-02-17 20:56:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-02-17 22:39:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Verified

Build Successful

subject: Rename v1.1 to v2
messages:
[{'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-01-30 21:32:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Do not submit

A few things jump out at me immediately:

1) if this is supposed to be a rename, why are we adding 20k lines? Shouldn't we net 0 lines added/deleted?

2) The version of the compute api is '2', not '2.0'

3) You need to rebase once more and simplify your commit message. You should only ever have one Change-Id line (in this case you want to keep the last). You can also provide a single summary rather than a 6 separate blurbs"}, {'account_id': 964, 'date': '2012-01-31 13:54:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Brian, we needed a full copy of the entire directory to provide unique URLs for reference. I think this causes the number of lines. 

I don't quite get why it's not v2.0. It's so annoying as a user of the API to have to keep track of when to use v2 (for Compute) and when to use v2.0 (for Identity). I've been in training classes where this is brought up constantly. Can we all agree on a standard or is it just too late?"}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-01-31 16:14:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

1) I still don't buy duplicating the code. If we end up needing to make a fix, we now have to do it in two places! Why can't we rename everything to v2 and add a redirect from docs.rackspace.com/compute/api/v1.1 to docs.rackspace.com/compute/api/v2? (I doubt those are the correct namespaces)

2) And I absolutely stand behind 'v2'. It has been a mistake to provide a minor version in our APIs up until this point. I've also discussed this with several people and the overwhelming consensus is to go with only major versions."}, {'account_id': 964, 'date': '2012-01-31 17:13:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Ok, I can do a redirect just on the web server, not a big deal. 

And if it's v2 it's v2. :)

Diane, I'll circle back with you on how to do these changes."}, {'account_id': 964, 'date': '2012-02-01 13:57:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

One more question - on the redirect and rename, do you think this is a good URL:

docs.openstack.org/api/openstack-compute/v2

or is this better:

docs.openstack.org/api/openstack-compute/2

The second one would follow what the rest of the API links do - no v. Would like your opinions, thanks!'}, {'account_id': 2448, 'date': '2012-02-02 17:40:36.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 964, 'date': '2012-02-02 18:35:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I have the Apache redirect ready to go once this is approved.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-02-02 21:22:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

Looking better. Please see my inline comment. Additionally, can you run 'git commit --amend' and simplify your commit message to this:


Rename v1.1 to v2

Change-Id: I51dbc34a300e94a2f2b464a1a68011204ebf064f"}, {'account_id': 964, 'date': '2012-02-02 21:35:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

These 2.0 items are in the pom.xml file which is the document build file. Diane, these should be replaced also. Probably it didn't affect your build since there are no figures."}, {'account_id': 2448, 'date': '2012-02-03 17:03:39.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 2448, 'date': '2012-02-03 17:42:51.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 964, 'date': '2012-02-03 20:24:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

I think this last patch set addresses Brian's concerns, and I've checked it over Diane's shoulder and I think it's good to go. 

Jorge still needs to review and I'd like Vish to take a look as well - can you guys get to it by Monday 2/6, since Gerrit now automatically abandons changes? Thanks."}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-02-03 21:50:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: (13 inline comments)

I started walking through the files again, and there are still several instances of 'v1.1'. Maybe I don't understand the goal here, but I would expect not to see '1.1' anywhere..."}, {'account_id': 964, 'date': '2012-02-04 00:45:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: No score

Hm, my best guess is that those samples are not used in the actual guide - hopefully Jorge can confirm that they can be deleted.'}, {'account_id': 143, 'date': '2012-02-06 07:26:22.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 143, 'date': '2012-02-06 07:36:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Updated the patch with the following:

1. Remove *.bak files, we don't need them we're using git
2. Updated namespace to v2 in WADL and relevant XSDs
3. Updated remaining examples to v2 namespace and confirmed that they validate against XSD.
4. Change the mimetype format so that it no longer uses a mimetype id (application/vnd.openstack.compute.v2+xml) in the docs and examples
5. Deleted really outdated examples that are no longer relevant in v2
6. Updated the version change history to denote that this is just a rename

Given all of this it looks good to me, but I'd appreciate looks it over."}, {'account_id': 964, 'date': '2012-02-06 17:15:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: (4 inline comments)

Just a few more cleanup items, and some embedded questions for the apache redirect.'}, {'account_id': 143, 'date': '2012-02-06 18:51:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: No score

(4 inline comments)

Got it, added comments.  I'll fix and put a patch out there."}, {'account_id': 143, 'date': '2012-02-06 18:53:28.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 143, 'date': '2012-02-06 18:57:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-02-10 20:04:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 2448, 'date': '2012-02-15 21:03:46.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-02-15 21:08:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

You should make 'Rename v1.1 to v2' the top line of your commit message. That top line should then be followed by a blank line."}, {'account_id': 2448, 'date': '2012-02-15 21:10:56.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-02-16 21:32:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 143, 'date': '2012-02-16 23:58:45.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 143, 'date': '2012-02-17 00:05:31.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 10.'}, {'account_id': 964, 'date': '2012-02-17 20:15:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Going to hit +1 Approved this afternoon since I think we're all good to go on this. I built it locally and it's fine, I'll change the Jenkins job(s) after 3:00 CST today unless someone stops me. Thanks all!"}, {'account_id': 964, 'date': '2012-02-17 22:33:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Approved

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-02-17 22:34:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Verified

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-compute-api-merge/26/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-02-17 22:34:15.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}]

Generalize xen network config

Allow dhcp for IP addresses.
dhclient3 bug workaround.
Refactor code to improve network creation logic.

commit_message:
Remove cloning of devstack

Now that we have split the scripts, we should not clone devstack.
We now require users to copy the xva over.

Change-Id: Ie7cb4858c3e5860ab5c990c5ed1f88462c6953dd

Good call Brian - I removed the pagination.  I don't think any caller would want/expect this to be paginated."}, {'account_id': 144, 'date': '2012-02-14 02:13:02.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 144, 'date': '2012-02-14 02:14:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

This does mean there's another bug somewhere else where someone is returning the integer instead of the UUID."}, {'account_id': 144, 'date': '2012-02-14 19:36:51.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 144, 'date': '2012-02-14 19:38:22.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 144, 'date': '2012-02-14 19:40:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-02-17 19:33:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

(1 inline comment)

Looks good.  Not hitting 'approve' just yet to give justin a bit to absorb my response to his comment (see in-line)."}, {'account_id': 144, 'date': '2012-02-17 19:47:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Thanks Kevin; I do think we're exposing those methods and even if it's not an actual vulnerability/whatever we probably shouldn't be doing it.  I think the "right thing to do" is to leave the comment in, open a separate bug, fix that in a separate patch by creating a new base class which has the common helper functions that the three classes need.  Sounds good?'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-02-17 20:09:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

'}, {'created': '2012-02-16 18:11:51.000000000', 'message': 'Enables hairpin_mode for virtual bridge ports, allowing NAT reflection

* enables hairpin_mode on virtual bridge ports on instance spawn
* adds conntrack DNAT state criteria to fixed/fixed SNAT exception so reflected traffic SNATs

* fixes bug 933640

Change-Id: I63b3e91b41898fcffda8a288be503f9b740b4b4e

commit_message:
Enables hairpin_mode for virtual bridge ports, allowing NAT reflection

* enables hairpin_mode on virtual bridge ports on instance spawn
* adds conntrack DNAT state criteria to fixed/fixed SNAT exception so reflected traffic SNATs
* updates get_interface ElementTree to work with Python 2.6/2.7
* fixes bug 933640

Change-Id: I63b3e91b41898fcffda8a288be503f9b740b4b4e

commit_message:
The security_group name should be an XML attribute

It is everywhere apart from in servers.py.  We have to be backwards
compatible, so we check the attribute first, and then check the element.

Bug #933785

Change-Id: I66b96376043e665a026eff5c33aa0731a81730cc

commit_message:
improve stale libvirt images handling fix. Bug 801412

If the unlink fails (because the path wasn't
even created for example), then that will shroud
the original failure.  Instead log failure to
remove the stale image, and raise the original exception.

Change-Id: I36c6968823bcf81d704319739b3a992dae75266a

subject: Fix bug 929427
messages:
[{'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2012-02-15 11:37:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Hmm, the change looks sensible, but I can't see the correlation with the libvirt docs and your xml presented in the bug.

I.E. There's a discrepancy between:
https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/929427

     <devices>
        <disk type='file' device='disk'>
          <driver name='file'/>
          <source file='/srv/nova/instances/instance-00000019/disk'/>
          <target dev='sda' bus='scsi'/>
        </disk>

and http://libvirt.org/formatdomain.html#elementsDevices

If the hypervisor supports multiple backend drivers, then the name attribute selects the primary backend driver name, while the optional type attribute provides the sub-type. For example, xen supports a name of "tap", "tap2", "phy", or "file", with a type of "aio", while qemu only supports a name of "qemu", but multiple types including "raw", "bochs", "qcow2", and "qed".

Are you not using qemu? I'm a bit confused.'}, {'account_id': 34, 'date': '2012-02-15 15:45:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

[{'created': '2012-02-17 20:09:29.000000000', 'message': 'Re-adds ssl to kombu configuration and adds flags that are needed to pass through to kombu.

Implements part of blueprint ssl-endpoints

Adds in configuration options:

kombu_ssl_version (ssl version)
kombu_ssl_keyfile (ssl keyfile)
kombu_ssl_certfile (ssl certfile)
kombu_ssl_ca_certs (ssl ca certfile)

This adds onto rabbit_use_ssl (which must be True for the above to have any effect) and allows
users to specify in greater detail (more than just True/False) how SSL is going to be configured.

Change-Id: I2186a6aa9397df857321324bf4007bc8310b85ce

Change-Id: I40d138823b6373b5fcf14f2d8f3b8368a727f4cc
'}]
commit_message:
Re-adds ssl to kombu configuration and adds flags that are needed to pass through to kombu.

Implements part of blueprint ssl-endpoints

Adds in configuration options:

kombu_ssl_version (ssl version)
kombu_ssl_keyfile (ssl keyfile)
kombu_ssl_certfile (ssl certfile)
kombu_ssl_ca_certs (ssl ca certfile)

This adds onto rabbit_use_ssl (which must be True for the above to have any effect) and allows
users to specify in greater detail (more than just True/False) how SSL is going to be configured.

Change-Id: I2186a6aa9397df857321324bf4007bc8310b85ce

Change-Id: I40d138823b6373b5fcf14f2d8f3b8368a727f4cc

commit_message:
Move translations to babel locations.

If we structure things like this, we can get things
actually, you know, installed.

Locales ast and oc aren't supported by babel. We'll re-import them
from Launchpad once we get babel updated.

If you want translations installed, run:

  python setup.py compile_catalog

Before you run either setup.py sdist or setup.py install

More work is needed to actually properly use the installed translations, but
we're closer.

Change-Id: I4a4bedd982c89063aa09688c9cbcf97054bcb34b

Fixes lp 919257

Return 503 "Service Unavailable" status from POST /images request
where there's insufficient permission to write image content to
the backend filestore.

Change-Id: I0c4e8bb1e70d6542852a86903a4a2a200dd23f01

commit_message:
Run ovs-ofctl as root

Since ovs-ofctl requires root privilege, nova-network would
fail during allocate_for_instance. This fixes the issue.

Change-Id: I188f1a4fdf4998c51f8626b37efd175039d23227

commit_message:
Print friendly message if no floating IPs exist.

Fix bug 932071.

Print out a friendly message from nova-manage when the "floating list"
command is issued but no floating IPs have been defined.  Prior to this
change, a generic error message would be printed, pointing to the log
for further details.

Change-Id: I0d11f93e9f51cf4e99e319bc9296f73380564257

commit_message:
LOG.exception does not take an exc_info keyword

It will automatically call sys.exc_info() anyway

Change-Id: I6a279bb18d913938d933a486e42a3be38bfaccb4

commit_message:
Allow file logging config

* Fixes lp904305
* remove module level log functions (getLogger to rule them all)
* Move specific Environment logging to the one place it is used
* Wrap getLogger to return a logger wrapped in a NovaContextAdapter
* Do not overwrite the root logger
* save_and_reraise_exception logs via error for passing exc_info
* Uses CommonConfigOptions for compatability across Openstack Projects
* Prefers CommonConfigOptions over legacy options
* Install a NullHandler on the root logger if configured by FLAGS
* Include example logging config file to mimic Nova defaults

Change-Id: Ie59c3f755c142e2b7dc3b94b4e82e142e157bfac

subject: InstanceNotFound exceptions for terminate_intance now Log warning instead of throwing exeptions.

(3 inline comments)

"}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-02-15 20:05:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (2 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-02-15 20:09:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 177, 'date': '2012-02-15 21:20:15.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-02-15 21:26:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-02-15 21:31:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Need Information.  I feel like the raise is correct here.  Any call that expects InstanceNotFound should explicitly catch and decide not to log an exception. If we want instance_faults to ignore it that is fine, but I don't think it should eat the exception in case the calling code needs it.  Am I missing something?"}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-02-15 22:26:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Vish: Yeah, that's a good point.  I mean, this is on the manager side.. so this is stopping a rpc.RemoteError from being raised on the calling side.  But it does seem like it should be returned...  even if it's likely from a race condition."}, {'account_id': 177, 'date': '2012-02-15 22:30:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

yeah this is no good. We should just log where the race conditions take place, like terminate_instance and let the rest continue to be real exceptions.'}, {'account_id': 2537, 'date': '2012-02-17 02:39:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-02-17 06:06:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

commit_message:
Get rid of distutils.extra.

We moved to DistUtilsExtra because it promised a more automatic workflow
from setup.py. It doesn't actually deliver though, and it also vomits
warnings during setup.py usage, and also breaks pip integration.

So this is going back to babel. Mostly folks shouldn't need to know
anything about this. We'll need to update the translations import
jobs in Jenkins, and we might need to add a corresponding translations
upload job that runs post-merge.

Translations installation doesn't fully work - but it actually wasn't fully
working before. Getting this part of the project done now though is a
pre-requisite for using tox for multi-python testing (tox starts by
creating an sdist tarball and then installing it into the venv, which
is just 100% broken with DistUtilsExtra)

Change-Id: I126e1bcfab0656eab6ca10de67d3d2aaa8b844f3

> There is only a single api-paste.ini in etc/nova which wouldn't be included in any case.

Actually that api-paste.ini gets copied in to nova/bin when using devstack. Actually, neither is there a nova.conf, but that also gets in to nova/bin in devstack.

> Also the old list was much smaller, listing the nova/ dir rather than every python file under that. Would it be OK just to list the nova/ dir?

I also changed this part to select files with "py" ext, to avoid checking on pyc files. This also happens in devsetack and it reduces the pep8 check time in half. commit_message:
Create a flag for force_to_raw for images

 * Allows for deployers to use compressed images if they prefer
 * Flag defaults to current behavior
 * Fixes bug 932180
 * Re-enables fetch_to_raw which was being skipped
 * Removes obsolete and broken method from libvirt
 * Checksumming will be re-enabled in a later patch

Change-Id: I40c33cfd3997cae8d127fa45f8cf0aa071418170

See inline'}, {'account_id': 2459, 'date': '2012-02-09 07:29:06.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 642, 'date': '2012-02-09 18:35:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Can you update the commit message to describe what the bug actually was and a summary of the fix, please?"}, {'account_id': 2459, 'date': '2012-02-10 07:51:03.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-02-17 00:08:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-02-17 00:20:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

The commit message could use some tweaking, but I don't think that necessarily has to hold up the patch.

The standard form is:

Short descriptive message.

Bug or BP Reference

Optional long-form description.


So in this case it would be:


Adding --force to mkfs.ntfs call.

Fixes bug 928749

During the process of creating an instance
for the first time from a glance server,
nova tries to execute this command:

mkfs.ntfs --fast --label ephemeral0
/var/lib/nova/instances/_base/ephemeral_0_500_windows

This in turn fails with this error:

/var/lib/nova/instances/_base/ephemeral_0_500_windows
is not a block device.
Refusing to make a filesystem here!

The reason is that mkfs.ntfs needs the
--force flag to create a filesystem in a file."}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-02-17 16:05:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-02-17 17:00:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Verified

commit_message:
fixed bug 928749

During the process of creating an instance
for the first time from a glance server,
nova tries to execute this command:

mkfs.ntfs --fast --label ephemeral0
/var/lib/nova/instances/_base/ephemeral_0_500_windows

This in turn fails with this error:

/var/lib/nova/instances/_base/ephemeral_0_500_windows
is not a block device.
Refusing to make a filesystem here!

The reason is that mkfs.ntfs needs the
--force flag to create a filesystem in a file.

Change-Id: If6c424400317a5f19ab117daec4c791476245753

commit_message:
removed unused method and added another test

get_network_id_by_cidr is not used, I'm removing
it and it's tests.

get_tenant_id_by_net_id relies on catching 
exceptions as part of the happy path. I expanded
the tests to try to exemplify that.

Change-Id: Iaf973da1d176ba8ea89d0fd762e796936d056d0f

commit_message:
Resolve bug/927714 -- get instance names from db.

I thought when I wrote the imagecache code for libvirt that the
instance names were of a fixed format. That is not correct. First
off the format is set in the instance_name_template flag. Worse
than that, it can change over time and old instances are not
renamed. So, now I check the database to see if the directory
name is a valid instance name (for this machine).

Change-Id: I318215aef5a10cee32959fd947ad628edff293a2

subject: Completes fix for LP #928910 - libvirt performance
messages:
[{'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-02-12 18:44:25.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 706, 'date': '2012-02-13 19:08:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

This works for me, seems to be a good improvement over the original logic. I've sent out a note to make sure we get this done for the XenAPI driver. Thanks!"}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-02-13 20:57:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Thanks jay.  The code looks good, although I'm a little leery of the greenthread.sleep(0) call.  I guess the issue is that we don't have monkeypatched sockets in the libvirt c library?  I wonder if there is some way that we could deal with that in a more general way."}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-02-14 15:52:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Hi Vish,

Yeah, I included the greenthread.sleep(0) call since it was raised as a solution in the original bug report. That said, this patch reduces the dependence on the _sync_power_states() call significantly (and thus decreases the frequency in which that periodic task is called) -- so I don't think there would be too many problems leaving the sleep in or taking it out :)  If you want, I can remove the sleep call and we can add it back in if Phil and others find the periodic task eventlet ends up blocking on that call..

Best,

-jay"}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-02-14 15:52:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: No score

Not sure why I -1'd that..."}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-02-17 03:59:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

Jay: Would you mind filing bugs for implementing get_num_instances more efficiently in xen/vmware?'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-02-17 04:10:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Verified

commit_message:
Completes fix for LP #928910 - libvirt performance

This patch adds the remainder of the recommended fixes
from the original bug report:

* Modifies methods in the compute manager that relied on
  the DB power state to be in sync with the virt driver to
  instead just query the power state of the instance from the
  virt driver. This enables us to set the periodic tick to 10
  for the problematic compute.manager.Manager._sync_power_states()
  method.
* Modifies the _sync_power_states method in the following ways:
 ** Replace the call to driver.list_instances_detail() to a new,
    driver-overrideable get_num_instances() call
 ** For each instance known by the database, call driver.get_info()
    separately inside the loop instead of calling the expensive
    list_instances_detail() method that can take a very long time
    to complete on hosts with lots of instances
 ** Call greenthread.sleep(0) before each call to update the
    database power state, enabling other periodic tasks to do work

Once again, I left an inefficient default implementation of the
new driver.get_num_instances() method in the base driver class. I
need help from folks who understand the Xen/VMWare drivers to do
an override for get_num_instances() in those drivers that calls
the underlying XenAPI or VMWare API.

Change-Id: I88002689cdda32124423da320f8c542e286be51b

subject: Add attaching state for Volumes
messages:
[{'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-02-09 19:44:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

I'm not totally sure this is the right approach.  We're trying to turn volume into its own service.  I'd like to get to the point where we aren't even using volume_api.attach and volume_api.detach -- The back-end should be able to determine if something has attached to it.  It makes more sense to put the volume into the attaching state in the 'initialize_connection' call. Since this could be called multiple times, it should only switch to attaching if the state isn't already attached. Terminate_connection could reset it."}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-02-17 06:03:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-02-17 06:03:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-02-17 06:07:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

We discussed this briefly offline.  I really don't like the attaching state being done via a generic "update" call because we are trying to expose everything to a rest api.  It sounds like we need a more specific call, like "reserve_volume" that could put it into attaching state.  Otherwise it seems like a useful change.  If you could do that change it would be awesome.  Otherwise we could merge this and switch it into a separate api call in a later patch.'}, {'account_id': 931, 'date': '2012-02-17 15:00:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I'll have a look at doing as you suggest."}]

commit_message:
Ensure StorageFull only raised on space starvation

Additional fix for lp 919255

Limit StorageFull to cases of genuine disk space starvation (ENOSPC or
EFBIG), in order to avoid confusion with 413 "Request entity too large"
status being returned from POST /images for issues unrelated to space.

Change-Id: Ib5e68e5d988d0f541803ffb3f37ddf88ac24e9dc

commit_message:
077_convert_to_utf8: Convert *all* FK tables early

The original migration only takes care of migrating the instances
table before all others.  It turns out, when using MySQL with InnoDB
by default, there are many other tables with FKs that need to be converted
early on as well (see bug description for schema diagram).

Fixes bug 931602

Update: Convert all tables in a predefined order from within the same
execution.

Update: Avoid hard-coding database, fixes bug 930863

Update: Fix pep8 spacing

Change-Id: Ideb619eecef2ad067bda5c26612f761674dee924

I understand from this thread there are plans to move cloudpipe to

Comments / Suggestions are welcome, since I'm not very familiar with the

there are plans to move cloudpipe / rewrite cloudpipe in quantum, this
might be an acceptable way to add the keystone authentication feature
for the time being.

Change-Id: I2c53986735baed4a262755b7f8c76c7b15cfbe21
"}]
commit_message:
Adding keystone v2.0 support to cloudpipe

As discovered here:

http://www.mail-archive.com/openstack@lists.launchpad.net/msg06581.html

There's no support for keystone in cloudpipe yet.

I understand from this thread there are plans to move cloudpipe to
quantum in the end. Since this is a lot more work, I made a patch to
enable keystone v2.0 authentication in cloudpipe.

Comments / Suggestions are welcome, since I'm not very familiar with the
nova code base, this might well need to go somewhere else. However if
there are plans to move cloudpipe / rewrite cloudpipe in quantum, this
might be an acceptable way to add the keystone authentication feature
for the time being.

Change-Id: I2c53986735baed4a262755b7f8c76c7b15cfbe21

(10 inline comments)

Do you think you could break apart the new functions you added to make them more testable, then add some tests? And please see my inline comments."}, {'account_id': 2256, 'date': '2011-12-31 11:07:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Hi Brian,

I need some more information regarding this. 

How do I break apart the new functions and add some tests? Also where to add the tests?

I am describing what the functions are meant to do. Please let me know whether you want me to do like this?

Test setup:

1.Controller node(running all nova services including nova-volume)
2.Compute node(running nova-compute)
3.VLAN networking manager is used.
4. Storage: An X86 server running opensolaris 2010.03 development build. It can run Solaris 11 express/Nexenta core platform or any OS that supports ZFS and comstar.

Following nova-volume flags that are added in /etc/nova/nova.conf file of the controller node:

--volume_manager=nova.volume.manager.VolumeManager
--volume_driver=nova.volume.san.SolarisISCSIDriver
--san_ip=<IP address of the solaris storage>
--san_login=<user having primary administrator role in the storage>
--san_password=<password> 
--use_local_volumes=False
--nouse_local_volumes
--poolname=nova
#poolname flag will make nova understand on which zfs pool the volumes will be created
Turn on listsnapshot property on this pool. 
 zpool set listsnapshot=on <poolname>
Functions/Methods:

1. create_snapshot: This function is responsible for creating snapshot of the zfs volume on user request.
 If you run "euca-create-snapshot  <volume_name>" command from the client, a snapshot <pool>/<volume>@<snapshot name> will be created in the storage.
Login to the storage node and run 
zfs list –r <poolname>/<volume_name> to check for that snapshot.
2. _get_snapshot_child_dataset_count: This function checks for presence of snapshot of a volume
If a zfs volume contains a snapshot we can’t delete the volume simply without removing the snapshot. Again if we delete the volume recursively the snapshot is deleted. But the snapshot record still exists in nova database with an “available” state. So I think one should delete the snapshot first and then only he will be able to delete the snapshot and the database will be consistent. When nova gets a user request (euca-delete-volume <volume_name>) for volume deletion, the volume manager first removes the export and then physically deletes the volume. So I made some changes in remove_export method, so that it checks first for the presence of snapshot in that volume and if not found then only it deletes the export. The method _get_snapshot_child_dataset_count checks for presence of child dataset in the volume <volume_name>. 
3. delete_snapshot: This method is straightforward and deletes the snapshot as requested by user.
Run euca-delete-snapshot <snapshot_name> from the client and wait for the deletion to complete. Once the snapshot is deleted login to the storage and run
zfs list –r <poolname>/<volume_name> 
In the o/p you will not see any snapshot.
4. create_volume_from_snapshot:
If you run euca-create-volume –snapshot <snapshot_name> -z <zone> -s <size>
A new volume will be created using the snapshot <snapshot_name>. Login to the storage node and list the new volume using
zfs list <poolname>/<volume_name> 
See the size of the volume using 
zfs get volsize <poolname>/<volume_name>
Note: In zfs we use to replicate a snapshot to create a new dataset. Here I have used below command (cmd_1 in san.py)
zfs send <poolname>/<source_volume_name>@<snapshot_name> | zfs recv <poolname>/<new_volume_name>
This command creates the new volume and a snapshot “<poolname>/< new_volume_name >@<snapshot_name>” along with it. We need to delete this snapshot. Below command is used to delete the snapshot (cmd_2 in san.py)
zfs destroy <poolname>/< new_volume_name >@<snapshot_name>'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-01-01 15:02:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(5 inline comments)

Hi!

I have some additional inline comments, please check those.

Also, would be great to add some documentation for this to the RST docs in /doc/source. The information you posted in the code review comments would be a good start of documentation about the new functionality you added.

Hang in there, Nilanjan, you're doing a good job... just a few stylistic things to fix up.

Cheers!
-jay"}, {'account_id': 2256, 'date': '2012-01-02 10:34:20.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 2256, 'date': '2012-01-02 13:34:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

I am not sure why Smoke Test is failing. There is no pep8 failures in the code.'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-01-02 14:23:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

After looking at doc/source/devref/volume.rst, I realized that it was not appropriate to ask Nilanjan to write docs for this new volume support if the existing docs were completely outdated and less than useful... so, thanks for the fixups, Nilanjan, and this lgtm.'}, {'account_id': 2256, 'date': '2012-01-03 05:22:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

After closing the inline comments I think it can move in.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-01-03 14:47:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

This is pretty much all bash commands, so don't worry about the unittesting I mentioned. Ideally we will get this to a point where it can be functionally tested. Thanks, Nilanjan!"}, {'account_id': 144, 'date': '2012-01-03 17:07:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(7 inline comments)

Great contribution, but I have some questions and suggestions (mostly about style & requesting a few explanatory comments), so I'm marking as -1 for now."}, {'account_id': 2256, 'date': '2012-01-05 07:15:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: No score

(7 inline comments)

Hi Justin,

Please see my responses inline.

commit_message:
Normalize odd date formats

The 'updated' value on the extension seems to be returned (in the XML) unaltered.
Some of the date values were 'untraditional', and this broke XML parsing.

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-02-16 23:02:50.000000000', 'message': "Add RPC serialization checking, fix exposed problems.

Related to bug 933584.

In this bug, I hit a case where some code tried to send a SQLAlchemy
model over rpc, which failed since it couldn't be serialized by Qpid.
This patch adds a simple serialization check to the fake RPC driver
using json.  It also fixes problems that were exposed by adding this
check.

If json can't serialize a message sent through the fake RPC
driver, it will raise TypeError, causing unit tests to fail.  18 unit
tests failed with the check in place, but it was due to only 2 places
in the compute API.

Change-Id: I63f3077c0fa35097d4f5d2c485f4e48eede2c751
"}]
commit_message:
Add RPC serialization checking, fix exposed problems.

Related to bug 933584.

In this bug, I hit a case where some code tried to send a SQLAlchemy
model over rpc, which failed since it couldn't be serialized by Qpid.
This patch adds a simple serialization check to the fake RPC driver
using json.  It also fixes problems that were exposed by adding this
check.

If json can't serialize a message sent through the fake RPC
driver, it will raise TypeError, causing unit tests to fail.  18 unit
tests failed with the check in place, but it was due to only 2 places
in the compute API.

Change-Id: I63f3077c0fa35097d4f5d2c485f4e48eede2c751

subject: Don't send a SQLAlchemy model over rpc.
messages:
[{'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-02-16 18:45:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

Abandon for now ... found another problem.'}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-02-16 19:03:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Restored

False alarm.'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-02-16 19:08:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Hm.  Not sure we would want to send pickled objects across rpc... especially sqlalchemy ones?  amqplib, which kombu and carrot use, default to json... which works fine on the sqlalchemy models.

An alternative fix:  Perhaps network info should convert the model into a dictionary first before trying to pass it via rpc.

Thoughts?'}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-02-16 19:14:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Yeah, I'm not a huge fan of it either.  I actually meant to post a question here about how common this is throughout the code.  It seems like most places are only trying to pass primitive data types anyway.  If this particular case is just an exception, I'd much rather just change the code so it's not trying to send the sqlalchemy model and let Qpid continue doing its thing as before."}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-02-16 19:21:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I suspect it's rare except for network api calls to network manager.  If you need an immediate fix for everything..  I'd probably choose json over pickle to match rpc/kombu.  I think that makes sense, anyway, in case the consume side is using json.  It's possible publisher uses qpid, consumer uses kombu for instance."}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-02-16 19:25:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

pickle seems a little dangerous to me as well.  I also think we should track down where a sqlalchemy object is being sent over the queue. It should probably be dict()ed or to_primitive()ed, because it has the potential to break kombu too."}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-02-16 19:43:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I don't think it's possible for there to be a mixed kombu/qpid environment.  They use different, incompatible versions of AMQP.

As discussed on IRC, I'll update this to not mess with the serialization in impl_qpid, and just convert the model to a dict before trying to send it via rpc, as is done elsewhere."}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-02-16 20:05:32.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-02-16 20:28:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-02-16 20:34:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-02-16 20:44:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Fails

Build Failed 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-integration-tests-devstack-vm/1529/ : FAILURE 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-merge/1413/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-unittests/1033/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-pep8/2794/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-02-16 20:53:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Build Failed 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-merge/1413/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-unittests/1033/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-pep8/2794/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-integration-tests-devstack-vm/1530/ : FAILURE'}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-02-16 23:00:49.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-02-16 23:01:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

dict(network.iteritems()) worked fine.  Changing it to utils.to_primitive(network.iteritems()) broke.  utils.toprimitive(network) works.'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-02-16 23:06:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Strange.. i figured iteritems would have been fine.'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-02-16 23:08:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Oh Duh.. I guess that makes sense.  to_primitive(dict(network.iteritems)) should have worked...  but no need to do that.

Cools.'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-02-16 23:20:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

re+2.  Really would like to revisit the dict conversion for models though.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-02-16 23:31:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Verified

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-integration-tests-devstack-vm/1541/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-merge/1418/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-unittests/1038/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-pep8/2799/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-02-16 23:31:36.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2012-02-16 18:13:12.000000000', 'message': "Use pickle to encode messages with Qpid.

Fix bug 933584.

The bug was that Qpid raised an exception when it didn't know how to
encode an object.  This patch applies a brute force fix to this and any
similar issue in the future by simply using pickle to handle the message
body.  That way the messages are just a string as far as Qpid is
concerned.

Change-Id: I63eb4bbabdb75fa7b277428bbd1aa2c2e1383383
"}, {'created': '2012-02-16 20:05:32.000000000', 'message': "Don't send a SQLAlchemy model over rpc.

Fix bug 933584.

I noticed this when Qpid blew up because it didn't know how to serialize
a SQLAlchemy model.  Fix it by making it only consist of primitive types
before sending it.

Change-Id: I63eb4bbabdb75fa7b277428bbd1aa2c2e1383383
"}, {'created': '2012-02-16 23:00:49.000000000', 'message': "Don't send a SQLAlchemy model over rpc.

Fix bug 933584.

I noticed this when Qpid blew up because it didn't know how to serialize
a SQLAlchemy model.  Fix it by making it only consist of primitive types
before sending it.

Change-Id: I63eb4bbabdb75fa7b277428bbd1aa2c2e1383383
"}]
commit_message:
Don't send a SQLAlchemy model over rpc.

Fix bug 933584.

I noticed this when Qpid blew up because it didn't know how to serialize
a SQLAlchemy model.  Fix it by making it only consist of primitive types
before sending it.

Change-Id: I63eb4bbabdb75fa7b277428bbd1aa2c2e1383383

Add is_service_enabled function.

Add a function to detect if one of the feature/server is enabled.
Some catch all for nova glance quantum

Thanks for dtroyer reviews and suggestions.

commit_message:

NotImplemented is a constant: http://docs.python.org/library/constants.html

NotImplementedError is an exception: http://docs.python.org/library/exceptions.html

commit_message:
Core modifications for future zones service.

Makes compute/network/volume API classes pluggable
Splits some code out in compute/api
Adds some race condition checking on deletes in compute/api
Make instance_delete support UUIDs
Add support to RPC to cast to specific servers
Migrations for future zones

Change-Id: Ibee126cd6d325e11770f27589e79dfd0e6104b99

commit_message:
Removed zones from api and distributed scheduler

There is a new Zones implementation coming that will use AMQP-to-AMQP
channels vs. the public API. This is being done for three reasons:
1. remove complications in the OpenStack API (and possibly allow EC2 Zones)
2. remove dependencies on keystone and novaclient
3. faster scheduling (fewer chances for race conditions)

Learn more here:
http://wiki.openstack.org/EssexSchedulerImprovements

Change-Id: I6fe538923dd5ae19276afac2ac3311a285fd5c99

commit_message:
Fixes user update methods.

1. Fixes the url for user update methods to reflect extension status,
   e.g. 'users/{user_id}/tenant' to 'users/{user_id}/OS-KSADM/tenant',
   as per Keystone API.

2. Fixes the update_user method, as it expects a POST instead of PUT.

Change-Id: I045ca7650b2ef8969af695900da1b4f62d4da6bd

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-02-10 03:30:26.000000000', 'message': 'add support for --config-drive 'boot' command

This just adds an optional '--config-drive' flag to the nova 'boot'
command.  It allows the user to pass in a string.  If the string is
 1, or case insensitive 'true': turn on config drive
 0, "" or case insensitive 'false' : disable config drive
 anything else: pass directly through to let it be determined server side.
   This would allow the volume id to be passed through.

Change-Id: I220e6d8d285243e708237cd9012093e62b67b6e5
'}, {'created': '2012-02-14 00:58:21.000000000', 'message': 'add support for --config-drive 'boot' command

This just adds an optional '--config-drive' flag to the nova 'boot'
command.  It allows the user to pass in a string.  If the string is
 1, or case insensitive 'true': turn on config drive
 0, "" or case insensitive 'false' : disable config drive
 anything else: pass directly through to let it be determined server side.
   This would allow the volume id to be passed through.

Change-Id: I220e6d8d285243e708237cd9012093e62b67b6e5
'}]
commit_message:
add support for --config-drive 'boot' command

This just adds an optional '--config-drive' flag to the nova 'boot'
command.  It allows the user to pass in a string.  If the string is
 1, or case insensitive 'true': turn on config drive
 0, "" or case insensitive 'false' : disable config drive
 anything else: pass directly through to let it be determined server side.
   This would allow the volume id to be passed through.

Change-Id: I220e6d8d285243e708237cd9012093e62b67b6e5
