subject: Don't fail response if caching failed
messages:
[{'account_id': 616, 'date': '2012-02-09 19:21:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Folks,

For the life of me, I can't figure out why I'm getting these test failures:


FAIL: test_cache_manage_delete_cached_images (glance.tests.functional.test_cache_middleware.TestImageCacheManageSqlite)
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/markw/devel/openstack/glance/glance/tests/utils.py", line 167, in wrapped
    func(*a, **kwargs)
  File "/home/markw/devel/openstack/glance/glance/tests/functional/test_cache_middleware.py", line 327, in test_cache_manage_delete_cached_images
    self.start_servers(**self.__dict__.copy())
  File "/home/markw/devel/openstack/glance/glance/tests/functional/__init__.py", line 517, in start_servers
    self.wait_for_servers([self.api_port, self.registry_port])
  File "/home/markw/devel/openstack/glance/glance/tests/functional/__init__.py", line 559, in wait_for_servers
    self.assertFalse(expect_launch, "Unexpected server launch status")
AssertionError: Unexpected server launch status


Anybody got any hints?'}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2012-02-09 19:38:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

This is to addres https://bugs.launchpad.net/glance/+bug/929762 by the way.'}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-02-09 20:11:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Can you add the bug number to the commit message and set the topic to "bug/XXXXXX" ?  That will get this patch automatically linked up with the bug.'}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2012-02-09 21:05:49.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2012-02-10 03:38:59.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2012-02-10 03:39:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Fixed previously mentioned test error. This is all ready for review.'}, {'account_id': 706, 'date': '2012-02-10 16:37:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

This looks good to me. After talking to you about the "new()" method I'm not certain of the naming but the logic is sound and I think it looks clean!'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-02-10 17:04:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Could someone enlighten me on why it was necessary to use the @classmethod new() in this patch?

Thanks,
-jay'}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-02-10 17:04:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 706, 'date': '2012-02-10 17:21:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (1 inline comment)

Inline comment for Rick/Jay'}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2012-02-10 18:21:49.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-02-10 18:36:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

LGTM.  The stub route feels a little nicer than either the factory or DI approach.'}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2012-02-10 18:38:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Honestly, guys, I wasn't trying to be fancy, just did it the way it occurred to me. I don't love the di_argument=None + conditional logic in __init__ because it seems less explicit to me. Also, I'm not super familiar with stubs--so it was really easier for me to do it the way I did it at first.

In terms of programming style, I just don't see what's good about stubs. The argument seems to be "we have a dynamic language, so we can hardcode dependencies in an object since it will always be possible to modify the namespace the object depends on." But the way an object depends on the namespace is generally a private detail that should be encapsulated, so I don't feel comfortable using this technique.

The whole idea of encapsulation is that small interfaces make it easier to have loose coupling. But stubs treat every private detail of an object as available for substitution, which blows the interface wide open and creates tremendous opportunity for tight coupling to creep in.

But again, I wasn't really trying to move glance away from stubs in this change, just doing it as it most naturally occurred to me.

Let me know if there are any other concerns about the DI style in the latest patchset. (Although I kinda need this fix in so if you'd let me backfill style in another patch I'd prefer that.)'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-02-10 18:50:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

Thank you, Mark!'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-02-10 18:59:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Verified

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-integration-tests-devstack-vm/1327/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-glance-merge/345/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-glance-pep8/524/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-glance-python26/3/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-glance-python27/3/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-02-10 18:59:48.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-02-10 19:05:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Mark, Brian:

Yeah the DI vs Factory vs Stubs is a good discussion to have. I see your point about keeping the details of the class private; on the other hand, what I like about stubs is that it keeps the implementation code fairly simple.

Instead of having multiple implementations of something (factory-methods), or having to pass in arbitrary code (DI), stubs keep that (invariably ugly) testing code confined to the test w/o making the original implementation code harder to read.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-02-10 19:29:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Build Failed 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/glance-tarball/361/ : FAILURE'}]

commit_message:
Launch screen with bash as shell

Since screen commands are bash specifics make sure we launch screen with
bash login shell instead of other shells.

Fixes bug928883.

Change-Id: I62b4c7182682deb4ef16ed0cf1a3b5a130c1c4ee

  volume_name_template=volume-%08x
  instance_name_template=instance-%08x

interpolation.

'}]
commit_message:
Disable ConfigParser interpolation (lp#930270)

This breaks e.g.

  volume_name_template=volume-%08x
  instance_name_template=instance-%08x

and is not part of the API contract anyway. We use $opt based value
interpolation.

Change-Id: I7659c7a304aac4d30a79751176ecf683bd664e6f

commit_message:
Disable ConfigParser interpolation (lp#930270)

This breaks e.g.

  volume_name_template=volume-%08x
  instance_name_template=instance-%08x

and is not part of the API contract anyway. We use $opt based value
interpolation.

Change-Id: I7ba566ae7c9a77322b52c67c5e1ffbffb760f0fc

commit_message:
fix virtual_interface_id downgrade

Populate the intermediary variables required
when calling downgrade.  Also don't populate
these variables if using sqlite.

Change-Id: I238a3aef1d9a0827f80461e8171e49bf8bca0a0b

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-02-09 23:21:57.000000000', 'message': 'Improved region switcher.

Adds the ability to live-switch regions, and bakes in support at a
lower level. Cleans up login-related code.

Makes the login view capable of being used as a modal dialog.

Overall UX improvements for region support.

Fixes a bug where having one region would still show the region
switcher inappropriately. Fixed bug 929886.

BACKWARDS INCOMPATIBLE CHANGE: If you were an early adopter of
the region switcher, you will need to reverse the order of the
settings tuples from the previous ("region name", "endpoint")
order to the new ("endpoint", "region name") style. This change
was done to better suit Django's "choices" syntax since the
original ordering was arbitrary.

Change-Id: I79db4ec1e608ee0f35916966c018d2a76b5ff662

commit_message:
Improved region switcher.

Adds the ability to live-switch regions, and bakes in support at a
lower level. Cleans up login-related code.

Makes the login view capable of being used as a modal dialog.

Overall UX improvements for region support.

Fixes a bug where having one region would still show the region
switcher inappropriately. Fixed bug 929886.

BACKWARDS INCOMPATIBLE CHANGE: If you were an early adopter of
the region switcher, you will need to reverse the order of the
settings tuples from the previous ("region name", "endpoint")
order to the new ("endpoint", "region name") style. This change
was done to better suit Django's "choices" syntax since the
original ordering was arbitrary.

Change-Id: I79db4ec1e608ee0f35916966c018d2a76b5ff662

commit_message:
Allow --token and --endpoint to bypass catalog

 * allows skipping of service catalog
 * removes odd logic about password equivalence
 * also removes extra call to authenticate

Change-Id: I5c0979107da99593b4ce8eb16c9695ba530da095

[{'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2011-12-22 21:29:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

I know you mentioned that these tag on to the rabbit_use_ssl option, but personally I think it would make more sense to have the options start with a "kombu" prefix instead of "rabbit" for a few reasons.

1) It's more clear that they apply to impl_kombu.py

2) impl_carrot uses rabbitmq as well, but these options aren't used there.

3) Technically kombu can be used with more than just rabbitmq as the backend transport (even though that's not really exposed via impl_kombu, yet anyway).'}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2011-12-22 21:31:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

revisions:
[{'created': '2011-12-22 21:22:10.000000000', 'message': 'Re-adds ssl to kombu configuration and adds flags that are needed to pass through to kombu.

Implements part of blueprint SSLEndpoints

Adds in configuration options:

rabbit_ssl_version (ssl version)
rabbit_ssl_keyfile (ssl keyfile)
rabbit_ssl_certfile (ssl certfile)
rabbit_ssl_ca_certs (ssl ca certfile)

This adds onto rabbit_use_ssl (which must be True for the above to have any effect) and allows
users to specify in greater detail (more than just True/False) how SSL is going to be configured.

Change-Id: I6d824cd23ed50d1bbe6f079436a2a0793627366d

commit_message:
Re-adds ssl to kombu configuration and adds flags that are needed to pass through to kombu.

Implements part of blueprint ssl-endpoints

Adds in configuration options:

kombu_ssl_version (ssl version)
kombu_ssl_keyfile (ssl keyfile)
kombu_ssl_certfile (ssl certfile)
kombu_ssl_ca_certs (ssl ca certfile)

This adds onto rabbit_use_ssl (which must be True for the above to have any effect) and allows
users to specify in greater detail (more than just True/False) how SSL is going to be configured.

Change-Id: I6d824cd23ed50d1bbe6f079436a2a0793627366d

Thanks for adding the tests. I have a few issues with test_swift3.py

1) You have mixed spaces and tabs for indentation. Please convert all of the tabs to spaces.

2) In FakeAppObject.__call__(), why are you only handling the range response for a GET and not for a HEAD? Both should return the same headers. I would recommend removing the check for the GET.

3) You modify the response headers after you call start_response(). While perhaps not a big issue in this particular test, it's not the "right thing".

4) You are doing a Range request and checking for a 200 response instead of a 206. Again, while perhaps not a big issue in this particular test, it's not the "right thing".'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-02-10 06:03:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

commit_message:
add content-range headers to partial HTTP responses triggered by "Range:" requests as required by the HTTP protocol

The S3 layer should not filter out content-range response headers as they are part of the
protocol and expected on a partial response.

Change-Id: I9992313361d85849740fdbf4aa4ecb53f0e32f4f

subject: ssl stall fix
messages:
[{'account_id': 866, 'date': '2012-02-01 15:25:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

From what I can read here:

http://stackoverflow.com/questions/8767757/python-ssl-socket-server

this seems to give a :

SSLError: [Errno 1] _ssl.c:1354: error:1408F044:SSL routines:SSL3_GET_RECORD:internal error

when doing do_handshake_on_connect=False.

I am not sure what could be the proper fix. 

I think SSL+Swift should really marked with a big *DEVELOPMENT FEATURE DO NOT USE IN PRODUCTION* banner when used.'}, {'account_id': 894, 'date': '2012-02-02 17:46:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

I agree with Chmouel. There are other issues with SSL, and it looks like is a Python problem (somewhere, perhaps it's in the SSL library).

I really don't know if it can be fixed to provide enough quality for production systems. One of the crashes is in the SSL handshake, but we got several timeouts in read operations too. At the moment, using an external SSL proxy (ie. pound) is the safest bet.

The docs should mention that using Swift as the SSL endpoint it's experimental, definitely."}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-02-10 06:03:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-01-30 18:11:22.000000000', 'message': 'ssl stall fix

Added fix to prevent proxy ports from being held open by something like telnet.

Test:

- - adjust proxy-server.conf so that "workers = 1" and restart
- - telnet to the proxy port and let it sit there connected
- - in a 2nd terminal attempt a 'curl -k https://<proxy url>'
- - or use a basic swift command to test connection - both curl and swift will hang indefinatley.

This update corrects that behavior.

Change-Id: I203986b03341cc525df25d5b5023f3bf8769f260
'}]
commit_message:
ssl stall fix

Added fix to prevent proxy ports from being held open by something like telnet.

Test:

- - adjust proxy-server.conf so that "workers = 1" and restart
- - telnet to the proxy port and let it sit there connected
- - in a 2nd terminal attempt a 'curl -k https://<proxy url>'
- - or use a basic swift command to test connection - both curl and swift will hang indefinatley.

This update corrects that behavior.

Change-Id: I203986b03341cc525df25d5b5023f3bf8769f260

commit_message:
Adds keystone auth-n/auth-z for Swift S3 API.

This capability has three parts:

a) a keystone patch to handle S3 credentials in /tokens API.
b) an new keystone middleware s3_token.py for swift.
c) a swift patch to use token and endpoints from keystone via b).

This patch contains c).

See:
blueprint s3token
keystone bug #874280

Change-Id: I8aecd59623466a6dd6ea5b7fce8b39b365325352

now that we are in devstack essex, lgtm'}, {'account_id': 1155, 'date': '2011-12-09 18:37:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Curious if you think it would be a good idea to make a generic fname-based pip install mechanism, kinda like the apts.  So if files/pips/key existed, those pips would be installed if key in ENABLED_SERVICES'}, {'account_id': 1, 'date': '2011-12-09 21:07:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

That sounds reasonable.  While we're on the subject, why not use pip-requires from the projects themselves?"}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2011-12-09 21:54:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

As we are seeing with nova now that it is using pip-requires, there is overlap between pip-requires and devstack's files/pips/* and  files/apts/python-*.  Is it reasonable to try and detect the duplication and not install from pip-requires if the module is already available?"}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2011-12-09 22:16:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Hi Dean,

I think that pip does that anyway... if a module is already available on the system or in the pip cache, it won't try to re-install it... so I think it may be a moot point, right?

-jay"}, {'account_id': 112, 'date': '2011-12-10 22:14:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: No score

The reason for not including pip-requires from the projects is that they sometimes aren't sane for development.

Each project takes a difference stance on what it means to be in tools/pip-requires.  Sometimes it includes things that are useful for dev - like nose - sometimes there are pips that are optional...  Sometimes projects have (or had) a tools/pip-requires-dev for dev and the normal pip-requires is for running it"}, {'account_id': 866, 'date': '2012-01-03 15:41:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

I like if we can as suggested by Ant the same mechanism done for APT as this may be a bit more elegant although a bit more magic other than that the patch LGTM.'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-01-24 06:03:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

commit_message:
Only install needed pip dependencies.

Only install pip dependencies that are needed by services
selected in ENABLED_SERVICES.  This is already the case for debs.

Change-Id: Iff1791bcd95e69d2e5a95179cbf55aafa4bdb307

subject: Added Zone_manager object as parameter passed to filter_hosts().  Fixes bug 874324
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 67, 'name': 'Vish Ishaya', 'email': 'vishvananda@gmail.com', 'username': 'vishvananda'}, {'_account_id': 335, 'name': 'Paul Voccio', 'email': 'paul@substation9.com', 'username': 'pvo'}, {'_account_id': 616, 'name': 'Mark Washenberger', 'email': 'mark.washenberger@markwash.net', 'username': 'markwash'}, {'_account_id': 688, 'name': 'Sandy Walsh', 'email': 'sandy.walsh@rackspace.com', 'username': 'sandy-walsh'}, {'_account_id': 849, 'name': 'fred yang', 'username': 'fred-yang'}, {'_account_id': 1132, 'name': 'Brian Waldon', 'email': 'brian@waldon.cc', 'username': 'bcwaldon'}, {'_account_id': 1247, 'name': 'Mark McLoughlin', 'email': 'markmc@redhat.com', 'username': 'markmc'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 616, 'date': '2011-12-08 18:43:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

It sounds like maybe you're making your own filter drivers outside of nova, but could you share a little so that I can understand what parts of zone manager you want to use? It seems like there could be some coupling problems giving full access to the zone manager to all filters. I just want to make sure we think through this carefully."}, {'account_id': 849, 'date': '2011-12-08 19:42:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

We were actually writing filter driver to run with the scheduler.  The key issue is we need to reference data cached within zone_manager.  The wiki describes what we want to achieve http://wiki.openstack.org/TrustedComputingPools 
And the previous patch was submitted https://review.openstack.org/#change,1899 which was using FLAGS to provide workaround hook for filter driver get back to zone_manager.  somehow the object was there for filter in Cactus'}, {'account_id': 849, 'date': '2011-12-09 17:29:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Mark, 
Have you gone through the high level of TrustedComputingPools?


To summarize, filter is designed to select candidate nodes (for scheduler) through service_states{}; for TrustedComputingPools filter, JsonFilterIntegrity is to scan for "trust_state" capability in service_states{}.  However, server_state{} is updated by compute nodes and can potentially be updated by malicious nodes to purposely fake the trust_state in service_states{}.  

The new manager_integrity is created to populate nodes' trust_state into service_states{} for filter driver, and tracks an cached trust_state information to make sure service_states[host].trust_state indeed reflect the real nodes' trust_state and not comprimised by candidate nodes.  zone_manager object passed to filter driver is used to perform post filter cached state verification.

TrustedComputePools is to verify nodes' trustworthiness, so it can't trust nodes' directly reported state, rather need to go through a trusted 3rd party to get trusted state.  Here 3rd party is a standalone, trusted attestation server hosted by cloud provider.

Hope this explains 1. why $trust_state can't be part of $compute capabilities, 2. why we need zone_manager object as  input to filter driver for post-filtering processing'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2011-12-09 19:29:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Brian Waldon and I were discussing the possibility of a couple different approach for trusted computing which wouldn't require adding a separate component and scheduler.

1: add an admin api to add and remove hosts from an availabilty zone.  Then the component that is verifying trust could periodically check the hosts and remove them from the trusted zone if they fail.  The scheduler could just use regular availability-zone scheduling to send the hosts to the trusted zone.

2. rather than verify trust during schedule, provide an external service that is exposed to users where they could verify trust.  They could basically request the trust state of an instance.  The service would speak to nova through an admin api to discover which host the instance is running on and verify the trustedness of the host, and return "trusted" to the user if the node passes.

Do either of these approaches solve your use-case?  They both require considerably less modifications to the nova source code, which is good for a number of reasons.

Vish'}, {'account_id': 335, 'date': '2012-01-23 18:01:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Is this abandoned?'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-01-26 22:27:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Do not submit

I think it should be. Zones and scheduling is being overhauled right now, so I doubt this would be a valid patch.'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-02-10 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-02-10 06:03:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity'}]
